Foreman.Action: Handles himself quite formally and is dogged in his approach.
Is at first wary of, and then impressed with the authority he has.
Not overly bright.
Tears a sheet from the notepad and tears up little slips of paper for ballots.
Suggests voting by ballots to organize the jury's decision-making process.
Checks his watch and compares it with the clock, showing awareness of time management.
Suggests taking a five-minute break to accommodate a juror in the bathroom.
Responds hesitantly and uncertainly when asked about seating order.
Suggests taking a five-minute break to wait for a juror in the bathroom.
Responds hesitantly and uncertainly when asked about seating order, saying 'I don't know. I suppose so.'
Climbs on the bench and examines the fan along with others, engages in casual group interaction.
Responds to 7th Juror's prompt to proceed with the meeting in a polite and cooperative manner ('All right, gentlemen. Let's take seats.')
Climbs on the bench to examine the fan, showing initiative to investigate the environment.
Responds promptly to 7th Juror's call to take seats, demonstrating leadership and control of the group.
Suggests seating arrangement by jury numbers to organize the group.
Politely asks the 8th Juror to sit down after he is distracted.
Suggests seating the jurors in order by their jury numbers to organize the group.
Politely prompts the 8th Juror to sit down when he is distracted, showing attentiveness to group management.
Politely asks the 6th Juror to knock on the washroom door, showing consideration for others' presence.
Encourages the group to start the discussion without imposing strict rules, showing flexibility and respect for others' opinions.
Uses a somewhat formal and neutral tone, not engaging in friendly banter or warmth with others.
Ensures all jurors are present before starting the discussion.
Politely asks the 6th Juror to knock on the washroom door to check on the 9th Juror.
Attempts to organize the group by offering options for how to proceed (discuss first or vote immediately).
Does not impose strict rules, allowing flexibility in the group's process.
Ends his remarks quickly without elaborating or guiding the discussion further.
Reminds jurors of the gravity of the charge and the consequences of a guilty vote.
Encourages participation by asking if anyone doesn't want to vote.
Counts votes fairly and announces the tally clearly.
Clearly explains the seriousness of the charge and the consequences of a guilty vote, demonstrating awareness of the gravity of the situation.
Organizes and leads the preliminary vote efficiently, counting hands carefully and announcing the results clearly.
Passively allows the vote to proceed without encouraging deeper discussion or critical thinking at this early stage.
Hesitantly asks who has something to say, looking to others for input.
Hesitantly asks who has something to say, attempts to manage the discussion.
Acknowledges the need to behave like gentlemen and encourages the disagreeing juror to explain his point of view calmly.
Interrupts the 12th Juror's doodling and urges the group to focus and move forward.
Acknowledges the need to focus on the task and encourages the group to do their job, attempts to steer discussion back to the issue at hand.
Interrupts the 12th Juror's doodling and reminds the group they need to make progress, showing awareness of time and group dynamics.
Supports the idea of going around the table to share quick thoughts, encourages orderly discussion.
Accepts the 7th Juror's suggestion to go in order without argument, showing fairness and respect.
Supports the idea of going around the table to share quick thoughts, facilitating orderly discussion.
Accepts the suggestion to go in order after 7th Juror objects to starting with 7th Juror, showing flexibility and fairness.
Attempts to keep the discussion orderly by saying 'Let's go in order here.'
Attempts to maintain order by suggesting to proceed in an orderly fashion ('Let's go in order here').
Only briefly intervenes and does not assert strong leadership or challenge weak arguments at this point.
Intervenes to calm down the heated argument between jurors, urging them to take it easy and keep peace.
Respects the jurors' rights by acknowledging the 5th Juror's choice to pass his turn without pressure.
Calms down the heated situation when the 10th Juror becomes angry and others start to rise, showing leadership and control.
Keeps the discussion orderly by asking whose turn it is and managing speaking time.
Politely prompts jurors to continue discussion by asking 'Anything else?' and 'How about the next gentleman?'
Does not interrupt or dismiss others despite some jurors being dismissive or sarcastic
Asks the 6th juror if there is anything else to add before moving on, showing control of the discussion and keeping the process orderly.
Accepts the 6th juror's 'No' and promptly moves to the next juror, demonstrating efficient management of the deliberation.
Tries to calm the tension by telling the 5th Juror to be reasonable and that there's nothing personal.
Interrupts the heated exchange to stop arguing and refocus the group on the task, pointing to the 8th Juror to speak next.
Forgets the procedure momentarily when reminded by the 8th Juror.
Tries to calm the argument between jurors and urges reasonableness.
Interrupts the discussion to stop arguing and push the process forward by calling on the next juror.
Forgets the procedural detail that the 8th Juror was supposed to speak next, showing a minor lapse in attention.
Insists on sticking to the agreed procedure and tries to keep the group organized.
Responds defensively and somewhat confrontationally when mocked by the 10th Juror, challenging him to take over his role.
Rejects being told to calm down and asserts his responsibility firmly.
Softly says 'I don't care what you do' indicating a moment of detachment or resignation.
Insists on sticking to the agreed procedure to keep the discussion organized.
Responds defensively and somewhat emotionally to criticism, escalating tension instead of defusing it.
Challenges others to take over his role to prove the difficulty of managing the group, showing confidence in his leadership.
Dismisses input from others with 'I don't care what you do,' showing a lack of engagement or facilitation at a critical moment.
Knocks on the door and quietly arranges for the guard to bring in the switch-knife exhibit at 8th Juror's request.
Rises and crosses to the door promptly when asked to get the knife exhibit.
Knocks on the door and quietly communicates with the Guard to retrieve the exhibit.
Calmly directs jurors to take their seats to maintain order.
Takes initiative to organize the jurors by telling them to take their seats to maintain order.
Responds to 2nd Juror's criticism of joking with a defensive 'What do you want me to do?'
Attempts to keep the discussion moving by saying 'I think we oughta get on with it now. These side arguments only slow us up.'
Engages 8th Juror by asking 'What about it?' after suggesting to proceed, showing willingness to listen.
Responds to a juror's criticism about joking with a calm, straightforward question: 'What do you want me to do?'
Attempts to keep the discussion moving by saying 'Okay. I think we oughta get on with it now. These side arguments only slow us up.'
Directly addresses the 8th Juror to prompt a response: 'What about it?'
Suggests taking a guilty verdict to the judge immediately but offers to stay and discuss if anyone votes not guilty.
Passes out slips for a secret ballot and respects the process.
Proposes a clear and fair voting procedure (secret ballot) to ensure honest responses from jurors.
Efficiently manages the distribution and collection of ballots, and accurately reads and reports the votes.
Does not intervene when the 3rd Juror disregards the secret ballot agreement, showing a lack of assertiveness in maintaining order.
Calms the group by stopping the yelling and asking for constructive input.
Intervenes to stop the yelling and calls for constructive discussion.
Suggests taking a break to wait for the missing juror, showing consideration for group process.
Calmly handles the evidence knife and returns it to the guard, demonstrating responsibility and respect for procedure.
Suggests taking a break to wait for the missing juror, showing awareness of group dynamics and patience.
Moves deliberately to remove the knife from the table and hands it to the guard, demonstrating responsibility and control over evidence.
Calls the jurors to take their seats and encourages starting the discussion.
Responds to a comment about dinner with a neutral, businesslike tone.
Organizes the jury by asking everyone to take seats and initiates the discussion by asking who wants to start.
Keeps the group focused by saying 'Okay. Let's get down to business.'
Nods towards the 6th juror to acknowledge a reasonable question, facilitating discussion.
Supports the old man's courtroom identification of the boy's voice, emphasizing its reliability.
Points out that the old man identified the boy's voice in court, emphasizing the reliability of the testimony.
Does not challenge or critically evaluate the old man's testimony beyond stating the court identification, missing an opportunity to analyze its credibility.
Calms down the escalating conflict between jurors, asks them to sit down and avoid fights.
Snatches the pad from 3rd and 12th Jurors playing tic-tac-toe, tears off the sheet, crumples it, and drops it in the waste basket to stop the distraction.
Calms down the escalating tension between 3rd Juror and others by urging them to sit down and avoid fights.
Attempts to restore order by telling jurors to take their seats after the confrontation.
Asks 5th Juror if he is sure about changing his vote, showing attentiveness and respect for others' opinions.
Announces the vote count clearly and neutrally without bias or judgment.
Accurately counts and announces the vote tally (nine to three in favor of guilty).
Asks for confirmation when a juror changes vote (Are you sure?).
Attempts to keep order and direct the discussion in the jury room.
Shows impatience or frustration with the slow progress of the deliberation.
Maintains order and attempts to keep the discussion on track despite interruptions.
Does not intervene effectively when other jurors talk over each other or dismiss important points.
Calms the room by asking to hold the yelling down during a heated argument.
Maintains order by reminding jurors about the vote and seating arrangements.
Calmly attempts to control the situation by asking to hold the yelling down.
Acknowledges the call for another vote and tries to organize jurors to take their seats.
Calls for another vote to clarify jurors' positions despite impatience from others.
Calmly announces vote count without showing bias or frustration.
Organizes the vote efficiently by asking who votes not guilty and counts the hands clearly.
Reports the vote tally accurately and calmly despite tension in the room.
Does not intervene or mediate when the 3rd Juror becomes aggressive and dismissive, allowing conflict to escalate.
Allows Juror 8 to request the diagram and considers the evidence carefully.
Does not interrupt or dismiss other jurors' doubts and questions, showing openness.
Does not assert his authority aggressively or prematurely, allowing discussion to flow.
Confers briefly with the Guard and takes charge of the diagram, facilitating the group's examination of evidence.
Confers briefly with the Guard and ensures the door is locked after the Guard exits.
Takes the diagram of the apartment from the Guard promptly and prepares to use it in the discussion.
Does not intervene or manage the escalating argument between jurors about timing and witness reliability.
Takes the diagram and holds it as the 8th Juror explains the layout of the apartment and the old man's testimony.
Calms the escalating tension by saying 'Okay, now... let's hold it down.'
Allows the discussion to continue without interrupting or dismissing others' points, showing tolerance.
Responds briefly with 'Okay...' to 10th Juror's aggressive comment without escalating conflict.
Calms the escalating tension by saying 'Okay, now... let's hold it down.'
Passively responds with 'Okay...' without further challenging or contributing to the discussion about the timeline and evidence.
Calmly reassures the Guard that the noise was just a little argument and everything is okay.
Responds tersely and dismissively to the 2nd Juror's lighthearted question about dinner plans with 'How do I know?'
Calmly reassures the Guard that the noise was just a little argument and hands over the apartment plan, showing control of the situation.
Responds to 2nd Juror's question about dinner plans with 'How do I know?', showing a lack of information or leadership in managing the group's logistics.
Laughs gently at 12th Juror's joke, showing lightheartedness.
Agrees to take another vote when suggested, showing openness and cooperation.
Suggests a fair open ballot and asks for objections, demonstrating fairness and respect for others' opinions.
Agrees to take another vote when suggested, showing openness to procedure.
Suggests an open ballot and calls out votes clearly and orderly.
Laughs at 12th Juror's unclear idea, showing light humor but not dismissive.
Calmly calls out each juror's vote in an orderly manner.
Acknowledges the tied vote without showing frustration or bias.
Systematically calls each juror's vote and keeps track of the tally accurately.
Does not intervene or manage the escalating tension or conflict among jurors after the tie is announced.
Switches on the lights to improve the environment for discussion.
Makes friendly small talk about the rain with the 8th Juror.
Switches on the lights when the room becomes too dark, maintaining a proper environment for discussion.
Engages in casual conversation about the rain with the 8th Juror, showing social awareness but not directly contributing to the deliberation.
Stands on the bench and starts the fan to help others in the room.
Shares a personal story about coaching football and expresses emotion about the rain ruining the game.
Stands on the bench and starts the fan to improve the room's environment for the jurors.
Shares a long anecdote about coaching football that is unrelated to the jury deliberation.
Politely asks the jurors to continue deliberations after a break.
Attempts to maintain order and keep the group focused despite tension.
Politely asks the jurors to continue deliberations after a break, attempting to maintain order and focus.
Does not intervene effectively to prevent the discussion from deteriorating or to manage the conflict between jurors.
Interrupts escalating argument and calls for calm to refocus the group on the subject.
Interrupts escalating argument and calls for order to refocus the group on the subject.
Politely asks 10th Juror to let him finish speaking despite 10th Juror's interruptions.
Tries to contribute to the discussion by recalling and clarifying testimony about the boy's psychological profile.
Attempts to bring up relevant evidence about the psychiatrist's testimony to support the discussion.
Struggles to maintain control of the discussion and is somewhat interrupted or dismissed by other jurors.
Acknowledges the psychiatric testimony without dismissiveness, tries to keep discussion factual.
Refers to the boy as 'a boy whoâ€™s always had murder on his mind,' which could be seen as harsh or lacking empathy.
Acknowledges the psychiatric testimony and attempts to summarize the prosecution's argument about the boy's potential for murder.
Does not intervene or manage the escalating tension between jurors, allowing interruptions and disputes to continue.
Acknowledges the tied vote count and asks for suggestions to move the discussion forward.
Does not intervene or assert control when the discussion becomes somewhat chaotic or dominated by other jurors.
Does not intervene or contribute to the discussion about the knife or the wound despite the confusion and debate among jurors.
Calls for another vote promptly and organizes the voting process efficiently and fairly.
Raises his own hand hesitantly and then lowers it, showing some vulnerability and honesty.
Organizes and calls for another vote efficiently, uses a clear and straightforward method (show of hands) to count votes.
Counts votes carefully and acknowledges the results accurately, including his own conflicted vote.
Appears slow and almost embarrassed when raising his own hand, indicating some lack of confidence or decisiveness.
Acknowledges the importance of reasonable doubt and the jury's role in safeguarding justice, showing understanding of legal principles.
Does not intervene or clarify when other jurors discuss complex evidence and testimonies, potentially missing an opportunity to guide or summarize the discussion.
Calls for another vote and asks if anyone objects, facilitating the voting process.
Does not assert strong leadership or provide guidance during the heated discussion, mostly acting as a procedural facilitator.
Acknowledges seeing the marks on the woman's nose and supports another juror's observation without dismissiveness.
Observes and confirms the presence of marks on the woman's nose indicating eyeglass use, contributing relevant factual detail to the discussion.
Struggles to find the right word to describe the marks, showing some hesitation or lack of verbal precision.
Moves to the door and knocks to signal readiness to leave after the vote.
Moves to the door and knocks to signal readiness to the guard, facilitating the process smoothly.
Does not intervene or attempt to moderate the 3rd Juror's aggressive and emotional outburst, allowing tension to escalate.
